brussels.Waffles: Belgian waffles come in two styles: Brussels (light, rectangular) and Liège (dense, sweet, caramelized). Best eaten warm from a street vendor with powdered sugar.
brussels.Frites: Belgium invented fries, not France! Double-fried for crispy outside, fluffy inside. Try with Andalouse or Samurai sauce.
brussels.Croquettes: Crispy fried balls filled with creamy béchamel and shrimp (crevettes) or cheese. A Belgian pub classic.
brussels.Moules-Frites: Mussels and fries — Belgium's national dish. Mussels steamed in white wine, celery, and onions. Served by the kilo.
brussels.Speculoos: Spiced shortcrust biscuits with cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves. The flavor in Biscoff cookies and spread.
brussels.Trappist Beer: Belgium has 6 of the world's 14 authentic Trappist breweries. Try Chimay, Westmalle, or Orval.
brussels.Glühwein: Hot mulled wine (German: 'glow wine'). Spiced with cinnamon, cloves, and citrus. Christmas market essential.
brussels.Jenever: Dutch/Belgian gin, the grandfather of English gin. Served ice-cold in tulip glasses. Oude (old) is maltier, Jonge (young) is smoother.

paris.Croissants: Buttery, flaky, crescent-shaped pastry. Best eaten fresh in the morning — look for 'fait maison' (homemade).
paris.Baguette: Crusty French bread with soft interior. By law, a traditional baguette can only contain flour, water, salt, and yeast.
paris.Macarons: Delicate almond meringue cookies with ganache filling. Ladurée and Pierre Hermé are the famous spots.
paris.Crêpes: Thin French pancakes. Sweet (crêpes sucrées) or savory with buckwheat (galettes). Nutella-banana is classic.
paris.Steak Frites: Simple bistro perfection: pan-fried steak with crispy fries. Le Relais de l'Entrecôte serves only this, with their secret sauce.
paris.Fromage: France has over 400 types of cheese. Try Comté, Brie, or Roquefort at a fromagerie.
paris.French Onion Soup: Caramelized onion soup topped with crusty bread and melted Gruyère. Soupe à l'oignon — perfect for cold evenings.
paris.Duck Confit: Confit de canard — duck leg slow-cooked in its own fat until tender and crispy. Rich and indulgent.
paris.Hot Chocolate: Parisian hot chocolate is thick, rich, and made with real melted chocolate. Try Angelina's famous 'L'Africain'.

strasbourg.Bretzel: Soft, salted pretzel (German: Brezel). Alsace's German heritage on display. Best warm from a bakery.
strasbourg.Tarte Flambée: Flammekueche — Alsatian thin-crust flatbread with crème fraîche, onions, and bacon. Like pizza's French cousin.
strasbourg.Choucroute: Sauerkraut (fermented cabbage) with sausages and pork. Choucroute garnie is the full Alsatian feast.
strasbourg.Bredele: Traditional Alsatian Christmas cookies in dozens of varieties. Families guard their recipes for generations.
strasbourg.Kougelhopf: Bundt-shaped brioche cake with almonds and raisins, dusted with powdered sugar. Alsace's signature pastry.
strasbourg.Sausages: Alsatian sausages include knack (like hot dogs) and the white saucisse de Strasbourg. Try with mustard.
strasbourg.Gewürztraminer: Aromatic white wine from Alsace — floral, spicy, slightly sweet. Gewürz means 'spice' in German.
strasbourg.Crémant d'Alsace: Alsatian sparkling wine made like Champagne but at half the price. Perfect for Christmas Eve.

zurich.Fondue: Melted cheese (Gruyère and Emmental) with white wine and garlic. Dip bread cubes with long forks. Don't drop your bread!
zurich.Raclette: Melted cheese scraped onto potatoes, pickles, and onions. Raclette means 'to scrape' in French.
zurich.Rösti: Crispy pan-fried shredded potatoes — Switzerland's hash browns. Often topped with cheese or an egg.
zurich.Swiss Chocolate: Switzerland perfected milk chocolate. Try Sprüngli, Läderach, or Teuscher for the real deal.
zurich.Birchermüesli: Invented in Zurich! Raw oats soaked overnight with yogurt, apple, nuts, and honey. The original overnight oats.
zurich.Bratwurst: Grilled sausage, often veal in Zurich. Served with Bürli bread and mustard.
zurich.Glühwein: Hot mulled wine (German: 'glow wine'). Spiced with cinnamon, cloves, and citrus. Christmas market essential.
zurich.Swiss Coffee: Strong coffee culture. Try a Schümli (crema coffee) or Kafi Lutz (coffee with schnapps).

salzburg.Kässpätzle: Cheese spaetzle — soft egg noodles layered with melted cheese and topped with crispy fried onions. Austrian mac & cheese.
salzburg.Kaiserschmarrn: Emperor's mess — fluffy shredded pancake with powdered sugar and fruit compote. Franz Joseph's favorite dessert.
salzburg.Mozartkugel: Mozart ball — marzipan and nougat center coated in dark chocolate. Invented in Salzburg in 1890.
salzburg.Wiener Schnitzel: Breaded and fried veal cutlet, pounded thin. Must be veal to be 'Wiener' — pork is 'Schnitzel Wiener Art'.
salzburg.Bosna: Salzburg's street food — grilled bratwurst in a white bun with onions, curry powder, and mustard. Local legend.
salzburg.Sachertorte: Dense chocolate cake with apricot jam and dark chocolate glaze. Invented in Vienna but beloved everywhere.
salzburg.Glühwein: Hot mulled wine (German: 'glow wine'). Spiced with cinnamon, cloves, and citrus. Christmas market essential.
salzburg.Austrian Beer: Try Stiegl (Salzburg's local brewery since 1492) or Augustiner from the monastery.

vienna.Wiener Schnitzel: Breaded and fried veal cutlet, pounded thin. Vienna's signature dish — always served with a lemon wedge.
vienna.Sachertorte: Dense chocolate cake with apricot jam and dark chocolate glaze. Hotel Sacher and Demel still fight over the original recipe.
vienna.Apfelstrudel: Apple strudel — spiced apples and raisins in paper-thin pastry. Order it warm with vanilla sauce or whipped cream.
vienna.Melange: Viennese coffee similar to cappuccino — espresso with steamed milk and foam. The coffeehouse classic.
vienna.Käsekrainer: Cheese-filled sausage that bursts when you bite it. Best from a Würstelstand (sausage stand) after midnight.
vienna.Döner: Turkish kebab in flatbread with salad and sauce. Vienna's late-night staple — huge Turkish community here.
vienna.Glühwein: Hot mulled wine (German: 'glow wine'). Spiced with cinnamon, cloves, and citrus. Christmas market essential.
vienna.Ottakringer: Vienna's local beer since 1837. A crisp lager, perfect with schnitzel.
